title: TIPP (Rapid Body Reset)
summary: A set of crisis survival skills to quickly change your body chemistry and reduce intense emotions.

details.content: When emotions are overwhelming, your body is in a state of high arousal. TIPP skills use temperature, intense exercise, paced breathing, and progressive muscle relaxation to rapidly calm your body and mind.
If you feel panic rising, you might hold your face in cold water, do jumping jacks for a minute, slow your breathing, and tense/relax muscle groups to regain control.

content: Use cold water or ice packs on your face or wrists for 30 seconds.
Engage in brief, intense exercise like running in place.
Practice slow, deep breathing (inhale 4, exhale 6).
Tense and release muscle groups from head to toe.

title: Self‑Soothe with the Five Senses
summary: Use your senses—sight, sound, smell, taste, and touch—to calm and comfort yourself during distress.

details.content: Engaging your senses can shift your focus away from distressing thoughts and help ground you in the present moment, reducing emotional intensity.
When upset, you might listen to calming music, light a scented candle, sip a favorite tea, look at nature photos, or wrap yourself in a soft blanket.

content: Create a self-soothe kit with items for each sense.
Notice what sensory experiences are most calming for you.
Practice using one sense at a time during mild stress.
Use self-soothing as a regular self-care routine, not just in crisis.

title: ACCEPTS Distraction Skills
summary: A set of distraction techniques to help you tolerate distress and avoid impulsive reactions.

details.content: When emotions are too intense to solve a problem right away, distraction can help you get through the moment without making things worse.
If you’re angry after an argument, you might call a friend (Contributing), watch a funny video (Activities), or count objects in the room (Pushing away).

content: Remember the ACCEPTS acronym: Activities, Contributing, Comparisons, Emotions, Pushing away, Thoughts, Sensations.
Prepare a list of distraction activities in advance.
Use distraction as a temporary strategy, not avoidance.
Notice which ACCEPTS skills work best for you.

title: IMPROVE the Moment
summary: Use positive coping strategies to make a difficult moment more bearable.

details.content: When you can’t change a distressing situation, you can still improve your experience of it, making it easier to tolerate without acting impulsively.
During a stressful wait at the doctor’s office, you might use imagery to picture a peaceful place, repeat a comforting phrase, or pray.

content: Use the IMPROVE acronym: Imagery, Meaning, Prayer, Relaxation, One thing in the moment, Vacation, Encouragement.
Try different strategies to see which are most effective.
Practice these skills during mild stress to build confidence.
Combine with other distress tolerance skills as needed.

title: Pros & Cons Before Acting
summary: Weigh the advantages and disadvantages of acting on an urge versus using a skill before making decisions in distress.

details.content: When emotions are high, it’s easy to act impulsively. Considering pros and cons helps you make wiser choices and avoid regret.
Before yelling at your teen, you pause to consider the pros and cons of expressing anger versus using a DBT skill to calm down first.

content: Write down pros and cons for both acting on the urge and using a skill.
Review your lists before making a decision.
Practice this skill even with small urges to build the habit.
Reflect on outcomes to reinforce skillful choices.

title: STOP Skill for Immediate Grounding
summary: A four-step process to pause and ground yourself before reacting impulsively.

details.content: STOP helps you interrupt automatic reactions, giving you space to choose a mindful and effective response.
When your teen says something hurtful, you Stop, Take a step back, Observe your feelings, and Proceed mindfully instead of snapping back.

content: Remember the STOP acronym: Stop, Take a step back, Observe, Proceed mindfully.
Practice STOP in low-stress situations to build the habit.
Pair STOP with deep breathing or grounding techniques.
Remind yourself that pausing is a strength, not a weakness.

title: Radical Acceptance & Turning the Mind
summary: Fully accept reality as it is, even when it’s painful, and choose acceptance again and again.

details.content: Fighting reality increases suffering. Radical acceptance reduces emotional pain and helps you respond more effectively.
You learn your teen is struggling at school. Instead of denying or fighting the facts, you acknowledge the reality and focus on what you can do next.

content: Notice when you’re resisting reality and gently remind yourself to accept.
Use the phrase, 'It is what it is,' to reinforce acceptance.
Practice 'turning the mind'—recommitting to acceptance each time you drift into resistance.
Remember, acceptance does not mean approval or giving up.
